memberdef.argsstring: (in this, in x_k, in x_dot_k, in t_k, in d_t)
memberdef.name: step

detaileddescription.para: Compute an integration step using the explicit Runge-Kutta method for a system of ODEs of the form $ \mathbf{F}(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{x}', t) = \mathbf{0} $.
Consider a Runge-Kutta method, written for a system of ODEs of the form $ \mathbf{x}' = \mathbf{f}(\mathbf{x}, t) $:

para.formula: \[ \begin{array}{l} \mathbf{K}_i = \mathbf{f} \left( \mathbf{x}_k + \Delta t \displaystyle\sum_{j=1}^{s} a_{ij} \mathbf{K}_j, \, t_k + c_i \Delta t \right), \qquad i = 1, 2, \ldots, s \\ \mathbf{x}_{k+1} = \mathbf{x}_k + \Delta t \displaystyle\sum_{j=1}^s b_j \mathbf{K}_j \, , \end{array} \]

detaileddescription.para: Beacuse of the nature of the matrix $ \mathbf{A} $ (lower triangular) the $ s$ stages for a generic explicit Runge-Kutta method take the form:

para.formula: \[ \mathbf{K}_i = \mathbf{f} \left( \mathbf{x}_k + \Delta t \displaystyle\sum_{j=1}^{i-1} a_{ij} \mathbf{K}_j, \, t_k + c_i \Delta t \right), \qquad i = 1, 2, \ldots, s. \]

detaileddescription.para: Then the explicit Runge-Kutta method for an implicit system of ODEs of the form $\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{x}', t) = \mathbf{0} $ can be written as:

It is important to notice that the system of $ s $ equations $ \mathbf{F}_i $ is a triangular system (which may be non-linear in the $ \mathbf{K}_i $ variables), so it can be solved using forward substitution and the solution of the system is the vector $ \mathbf{K} $. Thus, the final system to be solved is the following:

para.formula: \[ \left\{\begin{array}{l} \mathbf{F}_1 \left( \mathbf{x}_k, \, \mathbf{K}_1, \, t_k + c_1 \Delta t \right) = \mathbf{0} \\ \mathbf{F}_2 \left( \mathbf{x}_k + \Delta t \, a_{21} \mathbf{K}_1, \, \mathbf{K}_2, \, t_k + c_2 \Delta t \right) = \mathbf{0} \\ ~~ \vdots \\ \mathbf{F}_s \left( \mathbf{x}_k + \Delta t \displaystyle\sum_{j=1}^{s-1} a_{sj} \mathbf{K}_j, \, \mathbf{K}_s, \, t_k + c_s \Delta t \right) = \mathbf{0} \end{array}\right. \]

detaileddescription.para: The $ \mathbf{K}_i $ variable are computed using the Newton's method.

Another approach is to directly solve the whole system of equations by Newton'smethod. In other words, the system of equations is solved iteratively by computing the Jacobian matrixes of the system and using them to compute the solution. This approach is used in the implicit Runge-Kutta method. For this reason, a Butcher tableau relative to an explicit Runge-Kutta method can also be used in the RKimplicit class.

The suggested time step for the next advancing step $ \Delta t_{k+1} $, is the same as the input time step $ \Delta t $ since in the explicit Runge-Kutta method the time step is not modified through any error control method.

parameterdescription.para: States value at $ k $-th time step $ \mathbf{x}(t_k) $.
States derivative at $ k $-th time step $ \mathbf{x}' (t_k) $.

Project the ODEs system solution $ \mathbf{x} $ on the invariants/hidden constraints $ \mathbf{H} (\mathbf{x}, t) = \mathbf{0} $. The constrained minimization problem to be solved is:
Given the Lagrangian of the minimization problem of the form:
The solution of the problem is obtained by solving the following:
Using the Taylor expansion of the Lagrangian:

Notice that $ \delta\mathbf{x} $ is the solution of the linear system:
where $ \mathbf{JH}_\mathbf{x} $ is the Jacobian of the invariants/ hidden constraints with respect to the states $ \mathbf{x} $.

memberdef.name: solve

detaileddescription.para: Solve the system of ODEs/DAEs and calculate the approximate solution.

parameterdescription.para: [optional, default = false] Apply projection to invariants at each step.
[optional, default = $ 1.0\mathrm{e}3 $] If $ || \mathbf{x} ||_{\infty} > \varepsilon $ the computation is interrupted.

simplesect.para: A matrix $ \left[(\mathrm{size}(\mathbf{x}) \times \mathrm{size} (\mathbf{t})\right] $ containing the approximated solution $ \mathbf{x}(t) $ of the system of ODEs/DAEs.

detaileddescription.para: Solve without the solution projection on invariants/hidden constraints and disabled verbose mode.

para.verbatim: embed:rst:leading-asterisk * .. code-block:: none * * sol = obj.solve(t, x_0); * *

detaileddescription.para: Solve with the solution projection on invariants/hidden constraints and disabled verbose mode.

para.verbatim: embed:rst:leading-asterisk * .. code-block:: none * * sol = obj.solve(t, x_0, true); * *

detaileddescription.para: Solve without the solution projection on invariants/hidden constraints and enabled verbose mode.

memberdef.argsstring: (in this, in x_h, in x_l, in d_t, in varargin)
memberdef.name: adapt_step

detaileddescription.para: Compute adaptive time step for the next advancing step according to the error control method. The error control method used is the local truncation error method, which is based on the following formula:

where $ \mathbf{x} $ is the approximation of the states at computed with higher order method of $ p $, and $ \hat{\mathbf{x}} $ is the approximation of the states at computed with lower order method of $ \hat{p} $. To compute the suggested time step for the next advancing step $ \Delta t_{k+1} $, The error is compared to $ 1 $ in order to find an optimal step size. From the error behaviour $ e \approx Ch^{q+1} $ and from $ 1 \approx Ch_{opt}^{q+1} $ (where $ q = \min(p,\hat{p}) $) the optimal step size is obtained as:

We multiply the previous quation by a safety factor $ f $, usually $ f = 0.8 $, $ 0.9 $, $ (0.25)^{1/(q+1)} $, or $ (0.38)^{1/(q+1)} $, so that the error will be acceptable the next time with high probability. Further, $ h $ is not allowed to increase nor to decrease too fast. So we put:

for the new step size. Then, if $ e \leq 1 $, the computed step is accepted and the solution is advanced to $ \mathbf{x} $ and a new step is tried with $ h_{new} $ as step size. Else, the step is rejected and the computations are repeated with the new step size $ h_{new} $. Typially, $ f $ is set in the interval $ [0.8, 0.9] $, $ f_{max} $ is set in the interval $ [1.5, 5] $, and $ f_{min} $ is set in the interval $ [0.1, 0.2] $.

parameterdescription.para: Approximation of the states at $ k+1 $-th time step $ \mathbf{x_{k+1}}(t_{k}+\Delta t) $ with higher order method.
Approximation of the states at $ k+1 $-th time step $ \mathbf{x_{k+1}}(t_{k}+\Delta t) $ with lower order method.

simplesect.para: The suggested time step for the next advancing step $ \Delta t_{k+1} $.

detaileddescription.para: Check Butcher tableau consistency for an explicit Runge-Kutta method.
